title: Senate Says No to Military Action in Venezuela
summary: The Senate, which is part of the U.S. government, voted to stop President Trump from sending more soldiers to Venezuela. Venezuela is a country in South America. This vote happened because some Republicans, who are usually on the president's side, joined with Democrats to say no. It was a close vote, and it means that next week, there will be a bigger debate and another vote on this idea. Even though the House of Representatives and the president might not agree, this vote is important because it shows Congress is trying to have a say in military decisions. The article explains that this is a way for Congress to use its power against the president.

keywords.explanation: a group of people in the U.S. government who make laws
a country in South America where there is a conflict
when people choose yes or no on an idea
a political group in the U.S., some of whom voted against the president
another political group in the U.S. who voted to stop the action
the part of the U.S. government that includes the Senate and House

questions.question: What did the Senate vote to stop?
Who joined with Democrats in the vote?
Why is this vote important?
options: It shows Congress using its power
questions.correct_answer: It shows Congress using its power

questions.question: What might the House of Representatives do?

background_read: The U.S. government has different parts: the Senate and House make laws, and the president leads the country. Sometimes, they disagree on big decisions like sending soldiers to other countries. Venezuela is facing problems, and the U.S. is involved in discussions about it. This article talks about how the Senate voted to limit the president's power in this situation, showing how government groups work together or against each other.
Article_Structure: WHO: The U.S. Senate, Republicans, Democrats, and President Trump
WHAT: A vote to stop sending more military troops to Venezuela
WHERE: In the U.S. Capitol, focusing on Venezuela
WHY: To assert congressional power and limit the president's actions

perspectives.description: This vote shows how Congress can use its authority to check the president's decisions on military matters.
